a_text: We would have to assume that the sample display screens an srs and has no outliers and is aprox normal. /  / We conduct a z-test or t-test based on how large the sample is  /  / 2. define the parameters: / Mean # of display screens that are damaged /  / 3. state hypotheses: / Ho: the pop. mean number of damaged display screens is equal to the sample mean  / Ha: the mean sample number of damaged display screens is grater than the pop mean /  / 4. carry out a z-test or a t-test / chosen based on how large the sample is. /  / 5. interpret the p-value you end up with. reject or accept the null hypothesis, and identify error if there is one. /

You can look at the previous orders that have been made in bulk and see which have had bad display screens and which have not. If you figure out that majority of the bulk orders have had complains about a bad display screen then you know to reject the order. Although if there is about half the orders that have had complaints then you should do more research on the computers. You may need to do multiple tests on the computers to see what the odds of the computers having a bad display screen.
I believe the electronics company is doing a proper job with the more then 5%.

A random selection of screens should be tested. If there are more than 5% that are bad we can reject the order. It won't be always representative of the whole population but you cannot check each display.
